history.content:
Maybe try Stat134 as the tech elective. Stat134 basically covers the second half part of CS70, so you will be able to get ready in advance for the probability part of CS70.

````````````````````````````````````````

I noticed that you didn't have CS 170 (Algorithms) in your schedule. While it is by no means mandatory, it is practically the class that if there were to be fixed prereqs for Computer Science at Berkeley, CS 170 would be the first class on the list. It is useful in every branch of Computer Science and it helps you develop mathematical maturity and, in my honest opinion, an unparalleled level of problem solving skills. While CS at Berkeley gives you the flexibility to build your own road (which is a wonderful thing), one shouldn't ignore just how impactful CS 170 can be when building their schedule.

TL;DR --> Take CS 170. It's awesome and useful!
Maybe try Stat134 as the tech elective. Stat134 basically covers the second half part of CS70, so you will be able to get ready in advance for the probability part of CS70.

children.subject: I don't understand the "more internship" argument for doing 2.5 years. Wouldn't it be better to pursue a full-time position as a bachelor than to be a student intern?

To clarify, I wasn't suggesting 2.5 over 2. Just presenting a positive if you did.

You need 0 internships to get your dream job. Getting 1 internship is all you need to learn how daily Software Engineering works and to gain practical work experience before you Full Time. Getting more than 1 will absolutely benefit in terms of meeting people, but it's highly unlikely you'll learn just as much, unless you "upgraded". The idea behind the internship is, for those who have free time in the summer between school years, can gain experience to prepare them for full time work. I think people mistake internships as an entry requirement for work. It's not, just understand that companies want to minimize revamp time, so internships on resumes give recruiters confidence you can work on projects quicker.

Upgraded = 1st internship you didn't do, learn, meet people, much. I see a lot of sophomores and freshman take internships at small companies and have mediocre experiences, according to them. Then end of Junior year they get an internship at a medium sized place and learn a ton.

Revamp = time it takes to get a new hire ready to get rolling with work.

I personally have only interned once, for a big company, and believe i'm prepared to work in the industry now. I've met enough people, asked a lot of questions, and was blessed to be assigned awesome work, so I am ready to go into any environment, learn the technology, and begin working.

I have mad respect for people with the courage to persevere through school and challenge themselves by coming to a rigorous institution like Cal. Definitely hit up the transfer center and the career center.

If you transferred with a similar Data Structures course such as 61B, I highly recommend practicing for interviews and applying for an internship for Summer 2019. If you take 2.5 years, you can intern twice, which could lead to 2 great experiences :)

Congrats on getting into Cal and good luck!

history.content:
I'm a junior transfer, intending to do CS.

Currently taking CS61A.

I was planning on doing this: 

Fall 2018 - CS61B, EE16A, CS70

Spring 2019 - CS61C, CS1XX, EE16B

Summer 2019 - ??

Fall 2019 - CS1XX, CS1XX, tech elective

Spring 2020 - CS1XX. CS1XX, tech elective

I was thinking I could swap 16a out for a lower workload tech elective to focus on 61b and 70. Any thoughts on this and any recommendations? Much appreciated!
history.subject: Any particularly recommended tech electives for CS?
